stream_context.summary: Kaze reviews overall project progress (Course 10 update completed; more levels nearing 100%), begins new overworld programming/visual work (storm-cloud background that changes after a thunder objective), discusses tricky N64-era rendering constraints (water vs concave geometry; coin glow combiner trick), and introduces a major engine-side performance feature (occlusion planes) while also workshopping a new structure for the overworld Kamek encounter (shapeshift/disguise + 60-star gate via evil message blocks).
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces/ships a major performance feature (occlusion planes), finishes a Course 10 update and schedules the next beta test, and substantially reframes the planned overworld Kamek encounter into a star-gated narrative event (evil blocks → disguise/deduction setup).

findings.summary: Kaze says he recently finished the update for Course 10 and that the first beta test/first update has already happened; a second beta test is planned soon, with at least one more level expected to reach 100% completion on the progress tracker.

Progress-tracker status: several levels are in the mid-to-high 90% range, with two at ~96% that Kaze expects to push to 100% soon; other areas are “basically 100%” on his side and waiting on Biobak’s remaining work; four additional levels still need a first full gameplay test pass.
Coming back to the overworld after a few days, Kaze says he likes the area more than before—specifically praising the “view you have when you enter” as a strong first impression.

Kaze investigates/asks about a rendering issue involving water planes and concave geometry (e.g., a concave shell over water causing the water to disappear), and considers workarounds involving draw order/depth masking.

He sets a clear boundary: features that require engine-level hacks (like changing draw order globally) are “off limits” unless he expects to reuse them broadly, because they raise complexity and maintenance cost across the project.
findings.quote: Any feature that requires engine-level hacks—unless I want to use it a lot—I say it’s off limits.

findings.summary: Kaze announces the game now has “occlusion plates” (occlusion planes) for performance. He intended to demonstrate N64 performance gains but couldn’t show it on stream (teasing a separate video).

Occlusion-plane implementation details: the microcode can accept a single occlusion plane; Kaze’s system computes/supplies that plane from editor-placed helpers (4-actor plane, 2-actor cuboid endpoints, planned cylinder variant, and a possible second occlusion plane). The selection algorithm is currently buggy in the overworld (plane chosen too far from camera or even behind it), though it works in Course 1.

Kaze gives a concrete explanation for why coins can look “glowy”: he exploits N64 combiner behavior where values outside 0–255 clamp but small over/underflows wrap around, allowing an overbright range (conceptually like a modulo wrap) to simulate a pseudo-HDR glow.

Overworld visual/state change: Kaze prototypes stormy “dark and evil” clouds that will appear before a thunder-related objective is cleared, and then disappear/brighten after progress (star/state) changes. He adjusts render layering after realizing the background was being drawn in the wrong order.

Kaze shifts planning for the overworld Kamek sequence: instead of (or in addition to) a straightforward chase/fight, he explores Kamek disguising herself as a Yoshi in the village and using transformed “evil” message blocks as a progression gate tied to star count (e.g., 60 stars).

He identifies the core UX challenge with a disguise/deduction setup: the player needs an immediate, readable indicator of “who” is suspicious (e.g., an obvious visual tell like Kamek glasses) and a clean trigger that only activates after sufficient progression, without relying on meta-knowledge or arbitrary cutscenes.

Kaze notes he’s actively removing leftover vanilla Mario 64 code when he encounters it, suggesting an ongoing effort to de-vanilla/refactor systems rather than layering new behaviors on top of legacy code indefinitely.

biobak.summary: Biobak participates in discussing a potential rendering workaround for concave geometry over water; Kaze agrees a suggested depth-plane/draw-order idea could work but hesitates due to side effects (particles) and engine-level complexity.
Biobak is implied to be responsible for improving placeholder cloud art and is “pretty far along” on the Ice Cap rework, which is expected to push that area toward 100% completion on the tracker.

findings.summary: Raises a key constraint about the proposed depth-plane draw-order workaround: it may prevent certain effects (like particles) from rendering inside the shell, creating visual jank.

key_stories.title: Course 10 update finished and second beta test planned
key_stories.summary: Kaze positions the project as moving through a structured playtest cadence: Course 10’s update is done, the first beta/update has already occurred, and a second beta is imminent. This marks a shift from isolated level work to broader, trackable readiness across multiple courses.
key_stories.challenge: Keeping multiple courses moving toward completion while coordinating dependencies (e.g., waiting on remaining art/design work).
key_stories.process: He reviews the progress tracker live, identifies which levels are nearly complete, and calls out remaining tasks (waiting on Biobak; first gameplay tests needed for a set of four courses).
key_stories.outcome: Course 10 update is complete; several levels are close to 100%; the next beta test is planned soon.

key_stories.title: Occlusion planes added to boost real N64 performance
key_stories.summary: Kaze introduces occlusion planes as a microcode-facing performance tool: triangles behind a chosen plane simply don’t render, which can dramatically reduce scene cost on real hardware. The story is partly a triumph (feature exists) and partly unfinished (selection algorithm still wrong in the overworld).
key_stories.challenge: Overworld scenes are high-poly, and N64 rendering budgets are tight; Kaze needs systemic performance wins without hand-optimizing every view.
key_stories.process: He implements an occlusion-plane system where designers place helpers (planes/cuboids), then the engine chooses a plane to feed the microcode. He tests behavior across areas and observes incorrect plane selection relative to camera position.
key_stories.outcome: Feature works in some contexts (e.g., Course 1 shows ~5% gain) but is currently unreliable in the overworld; he plans to fix selection logic before showcasing results.

key_stories.title: Choosing not to ‘engine-hack’ a water/concave-geometry rendering fix
key_stories.summary: A common ROM-hack temptation is to solve one visual bug with a special-case engine change. Kaze explicitly rejects that approach here, prioritizing maintainability and consistency over a clever-but-fragile fix.
key_stories.challenge: Concave geometry over a water plane can cause water/visibility artifacts; a proposed solution involves changing render order and using depth masking.
key_stories.process: Kaze and chat explore a depth-plane approach that would likely fix the artifact, but he enumerates costs: particles may fail to render correctly and it would require supporting draw-order manipulation in his engine.
key_stories.outcome: He effectively shelves the approach unless it becomes broadly useful across the game, establishing a project-wide decision rule.
key_stories.key_quote: Any feature that requires engine-level hacks—unless I want to use it a lot—I say it’s off limits.

key_stories.title: Reframing the overworld Kamek encounter into a 60-star gated ‘disguise’ event
key_stories.summary: Instead of a simple boss arena, Kaze explores making Kamek’s presence felt as an overworld narrative disruption: Yoshis transformed into hostile rhyme-insulting message blocks that gate progression until the player reaches a star threshold. After the gate, the blocks reveal Kamek has disguised herself as a Yoshi, creating a Mario-64-ified ‘detective setting.’
key_stories.challenge: He wants a memorable overworld confrontation that doesn’t break traversal, doesn’t rely on awkward cutscene logic, and clearly communicates objectives to players.
key_stories.process: He iterates through multiple concepts (Kamek chase; ice-on-lake traversal; transforming Yoshis into attacking blocks; then a disguise setup). He repeatedly tests each idea against clarity (“how would players figure it out?”) and progression gating (must not be solvable early).
key_stories.outcome: A workable spine emerges: evil blocks taunt the player to reach ~60 stars; upon success they divulge the disguise twist and/or revert, enabling a controlled trigger and readable midgame event. Kaze writes the idea down as a candidate plan.

open_questions.context: Kaze’s occlusion plane system can be fed by planes/cuboids (and potentially cylinders), but the algorithm currently chooses planes that are too far, not closest to camera, or even behind it—especially in the overworld.
questions: What exact heuristic did you intend for ‘best’ occlusion plane (closest to camera, smallest plane, maximum occluded triangles, or something else)?
How did you design the editor workflow (actors/handles) so level designers can place occlusion volumes without constantly debugging them?
At what point do you decide the system is ‘reliable enough’ to roll out across many courses, and what metrics on real N64 will you use to prove it?
You mentioned a second occlusion plane and a cylinder variant—what scenes require those, and how much complexity are you willing to add to get the extra wins?

open_questions.topic: Overworld storm-cloud state change (pre/post thunder objective)
open_questions.context: Kaze prototypes stormy clouds as a temporary/early-game state that disappears after beating a thunder-related objective, and he had to correct draw-layer ordering to make it render properly.
questions: What is the exact player-facing event that clears the ‘storm state’—is it a star, a boss, or a world event flag?
How do you want players to interpret the storm clouds narratively (warning, blockade, mood), and how explicit will the game be about that?
What’s the final art/animation plan for these clouds—how much is placeholder vs. the intended look once Biobak revisits them?

open_questions.topic: Designing the Kamek overworld encounter so it’s readable and ‘Mario 64-ified’
open_questions.context: Kaze likes the idea of Kamek disguising herself as a Yoshi and using evil message blocks as a midgame progression gate (e.g., 60 stars), but he worries a true detective mission could ‘suck’ without clear player guidance.
questions: What would be the single strongest visual/behavioral tell that makes the disguised Kamek legible without a walkthrough (e.g., glasses, unique hat, dialogue cadence, animation)?
How do you plan to trigger the event cleanly at ~60 stars—instant overworld cutscene, NPC approach, map/letter, or something else?
What is the player’s concrete action to ‘prove’ the disguise—talk options, item/flag check, a mini-challenge, or a short fight?
Where does the reward land in the progression—does it unlock a new overworld path, remove blockades, grant a star, or all of the above?

open_questions.topic: Coin glow rendering trick and broader material/lighting strategy
open_questions.context: Kaze explains the coin glow effect as an intentional exploitation of N64 combiner wrap-around/overbright range (pseudo-HDR behavior).
questions: When did you first discover/decide to use the combiner wrap-around trick—was it inherited from vanilla SM64 coins or something you tuned specifically for RTYI?
Are there other materials you plan to ‘overbright’ this way (gems, magic, lightning), and how do you keep it consistent across courses?
Does this technique have emulator-vs-hardware differences you’ve had to account for, especially with different graphics plugins?
